component.name: Twine
component.summary: Twine is an open-source tool for telling interactive, nonlinear stories

description.p: Twine is an open-source tool for telling interactive, nonlinear stories.
You don't need to write any code to create a simple story with Twine, but you can extend your stories with variables, conditional logic, images, CSS, and JavaScript when you're ready.
Twine publishes directly to HTML, so you can post your work nearly anywhere. Anything you create with it is completely free to use any way you like, including for commercial purposes.
Twine was originally created by Chris Klimas in 2009 and is now maintained by a whole bunch of people at several different repositories.

ul.li: Story format list is now a dialog instead of a separate screen
New preference has been added that allows disabling enhanced text editors, which can have problems with assistive technology
data-tag attribute is added to passage cards in the story map, which can be targeted using custom CSS
New preferences have been added for changing the location of the story library, and for disabling hardware accelerated graphics
Passage edit dialogs now show leading and trailing whitespace in passage names as ‚ê£ symbols to help tracking down accidental spaces
Zoom controls in the story map have been moved into the top toolbar, so that the amount of space in the story map is increased
"Start Story Here" checkbox in passage edit dialogs has been replaced with "Test from Here"
When a second passage edit dialog is opened after one is already open, the new dialog appears on top of the existing one, forming a stack
Added a Go To button to the story map toolbar, which allows moving to a passage by name
Passages considered "empty" now show with a translucent background
If the last link to an empty passage is removed, an empty passage will be deleted
All detail dialogs, like the find and replace text dialog, are now modeless, meaning that you can do other work in your story while they're open
Desktop app now uses Electron instead of NW.js
Files in the story directory are now published as full-fledged stories, where possible
